<hr>
<h3><a id="user-content-objectives" class="anchor" href="#objectives" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Objectives</h3>
<ol>
<li>Understand why R Markdown can be useful sometimes</li>
<li>Get familiar with the Markdown language</li>
<li>Integrate R scripting into Markdown</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<h3><a id="user-content-markdown" class="anchor" href="#markdown" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Markdown</h3>
<p><strong>What is Markdown?</strong></p>
<p>"Markdown is a text-to-HTML conversion tool for web writers." <em>Source: <a href="http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/">Markdown Web page</a></em></p>
<p><strong>Why Markdown has become so popular?</strong></p>
<p>Because...</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>it is easy. To beign with all you need to learn is just the first <a href="https://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/rmarkdown-reference.pdf">page</a>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>it is fast and clean; you make less mistakes -&gt; increases efficiency. Here is an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown">example</a>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>it is portable; your documents can be edited in any text application on any operating system.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>it is flexible;</p>
<ul>
<li>many other platforms/languages are using it, e.g. Dropbox, Github and of course R.</li>
<li>variety in applications (e.g. emails, webpages, presentations, even books!)</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>So, why R Markdown?</strong></p>
<hr>
<h3><a id="user-content-r-markdown" class="anchor" href="#r-markdown" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>R Markdown</h3>
<p>R Markdown has some significant strengths:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Supports many formats (HTML, PDF, Word), which..</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Helps us present/teach a specific method in R, which..</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Allows collaborative science and coding (cloud-computing), and also..</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Enables reproducible research and reporting.</p>
<ul>
<li>What is <a href="http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2016WR019285/abstract">reproducible research?</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.nature.com/news/1-500-scientists-lift-the-lid-on-reproducibility-1.19970">Why is it important?</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><em>Takeaway message: "Sharing methods and data is strength, not a weakness."</em></p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Installing R Markdown</strong></p>
<p>Like the rest of R, R Markdown is free and open source. You can install the R Markdown package from CRAN with:</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>#install.packages("jsonlite", type="binary")
#install.packages("base64enc", type="binary")
#install.packages('knitr', dependencies = TRUE)
#install.packages("rmarkdown")   
</code></pre>
<p><strong>Create a Markdown &amp; an HTML file</strong></p>
<p>To create a new markdown file: File/New File/R Markdown...</p>
<p>This is a plain text file that has the extension .Rmd</p>
<p>Notice that the file contains three types of content:</p>
<ul>
<li>A header surrounded by <code>---</code></li>
<li>R code surrounded by ``` [we call them chunks and can create a new one we use the Insert button [or Ctr+Alt+I] &amp; discover another strength of Markdown; any ideas??]</li>
<li>text mixed with some simple text formatting</li>
</ul>
<p>To create an html [PDF/word] file, we press the Knit button [or Ctr+Shift+K].</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Markdown formating</strong></p>
<blockquote>
<p>Following the syntax rules we have seen <a href="https://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/rmarkdown-reference.pdf">here</a>, try to make the following changes to the original rmd file:</p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>Change any <strong>bold</strong> formating to <em>italics</em>.</li>
<li>Create a sub-heading below the original one (Markdown).</li>
<li>Replace <a href="http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com">http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com</a> to the phrase "this link", but keep the link.</li>
<li>Add the following text [from "Including..." to "...this"] in the end of the file:</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<h4><a id="user-content-including-equations" class="anchor" href="#including-equations" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Including Equations</h4>
<p>You can also add equations, such as:</p>
<p>$$
f(x) = e^x
$$
$$
f'(x) = x^2(a_1+a_2)
$$
$$
A = \pi \rho^2
$$</p>
<p>To find out how to write greek letters or use complex mathematical formulations check <a href="https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX/Mathematics">this</a>.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>R scripting</strong></p>
<p>Each code chunk can be run seperately.</p>
<p>When you knit your .Rmd file, RMarkdown will run all the code chunks and embed their results beneath them.</p>
<p>Remember: <em>When knitting, Rmarkdown will not use anything outside the code chunks, e.g. other variables created in our workspace.</em></p>
<blockquote>
<p>Report some results from the previous lesson.</p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>Download and import the dataset [data_PRT.csv].</li>
<li>Replace the data frame summary chunk, add the str() command to examine its structure.</li>
<li>Replace the plot in the other chunk with the set of histograms you have made in the previous lesson [transform data to tidy format].</li>
<li>The headings should now be "Data description" and "Empirical distributions".</li>
<li>Delete all the irrelevant text.</li>
<li>Knit it!</li>
</ul>
<pre lang="{r"><code>setwd("/home/yannis/Dokumenty/R/RMarkdown")
pr = read.csv('data_PRT.csv', sep = ';') 
str(pr)
summary(pr)
</code></pre>
<pre lang="{r"><code>library(ggplot2)
library(reshape2)

pr = melt(pr)
ggplot(pr) + geom_histogram(aes(x = value), col = 'grey20') + facet_grid(ID~variable, scales = "free") + theme_gray(base_size = 10, base_family = "")
</code></pre>
<hr>
<p><strong>Pandoc and LaTeX</strong></p>
<p>During knitting the following things happen:</p>
<ol>
<li>R Markdown feeds the .Rmd file to <a href="http://yihui.name/knitr/">knitr</a>.</li>
<li>Knitr executes all of the code chunks and creates a new markdown (.md) document.</li>
<li>The markdown file is then processed by <a href="http://pandoc.org/">pandoc</a> which creates the finished format.</li>
</ol>
<p>Among the many formats pandoc can convert a the .md file to <a href="http://www.latex-project.org/">LaTeX</a>.</p>
<p>Why to use LaTeX and why <a href="https://www.overleaf.com/6258626cgrkxt#/21001967/">not</a>? <em>"LaTeX makes difficult things easy, and easy things very difficult."</em></p>
<p>The file that mixes R code chunks and LaTeX has the extension .Rnw.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Knit the report to a PDF file [LaTeX format].</p>
</blockquote>
<hr>
<p><strong>Basic chunk options</strong></p>
<p>With knitr::opts_chunk$set we can set some global options for our code chunks. The cache option is one of them; R saves the content of each chunk and does not run it as long as it remains unchanged.</p>
<p>Some other options, which can be also used to each code chunk are:</p>
<ul>
<li>echo</li>
<li>include</li>
<li>message</li>
<li>fig.width, fig.height
<ul>
<li>small: &lt;4</li>
<li>medium: 4-8</li>
<li>big: &gt;8</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>fig.align</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>With the <code>echo</code> option, we can share our code easily with our collaborators:</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, month(pr$DTM), pr$variable), mean) #Martin, do you know if tapply() should be used like this? [the results seem ok]
</code></pre>
<hr>
<p><strong>Tables</strong></p>
<p>The knitr package also offers another useful function: kable()</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>aa = data.frame(ID = 1:10,  Value = rnorm(10), Type = sample(c('A', 'B', 'C', 'D'), 10, replace = TRUE))
knitr::kable(aa, caption = "A simple table with kable()")
</code></pre>
<blockquote>
<p>Let's try to make a better table.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>A new code chunk with a table showing the means of each variable per station.</p>
<pre lang="{r"><code>aa = tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, pr$variable), mean)
knitr::kable(aa, caption = "A better table with kable()", digits = 2)
</code></pre>
<p>The function that helps us estimate the means is tapply(). Its syntax is quite simple and we use it often with tidy data:</p>
<p>tapply(val, id, fun) is translated to: <em>Apply function "fun" to the values "val" of each category "id"</em></p>
<p>We can apply the function to more than one identificators by making a list of them, e.g.:</p>
<p>tapply(val, list(id.var1, id.var2, id.var3), fun).</p>
<p>Is there any alternative way to do this?</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>In line text</strong></p>
<p>It is not necessary to create code chunks to present our results. We can add them by using the ```'r' some code ``` formulation.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Add the following text with the results</p>
</blockquote>
<pre lang="{r"><code>pr.mean = tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, pr$variable), mean)
pr.sd = tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, pr$variable), sd)
pr.max = tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, pr$variable), max)
</code></pre>
<p>In terms of precipitation our data have a mean of <code>r mean(pr.mean[,1])</code> with standard deviation <code>r mean(pr.sd[,1])</code> and a maximum of <code>r max(pr.max[,1])</code> at <code>r rownames(pr.max)[which.max(pr.max[,1])]</code>.</p>
<hr>
<p>The true strength of Rmarkdown is that in this way our report is dynamic. For example, if the Hradiste station is erroneous and should be removed, than we just remove him and re-knit our rmd file:</p>
<hr>
<pre lang="{r"><code>pr = pr[ID != "HRADISTE"]
pr = droplevels(pr)
pr.mean = tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, pr$variable), mean, na.rm = T)
pr.sd = tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, pr$variable), sd)
pr.max = tapply(pr$value, list(pr$ID, pr$variable), max)
</code></pre>
<p>In terms of precipitation our data have a mean of <code>r mean(pr.mean[,1])</code> with standard deviation <code>r mean(pr.sd[,1])</code> and a maximum of <code>r max(pr.max[,1])</code> at <code>r rownames(pr.max)[which.max(pr.max[,1])]</code>.</p>
<p><strong>Finalizing our work</strong></p>
<p>We can use the theme option in the header section to specify the theme to use for the page. The theme names are "default", "cerulean", "journal", "flatly", "readable", "spacelab", "united", "cosmo", "lumen", "paper", "sandstone", "simplex", and "yeti". For example:</p>
<pre><code>---
title: "EDA"
output:
  html_document:
    theme: united
---
</code></pre>
<p>We can also add a table of contents using the toc option and section numbering to headers using the <code>number_sections</code> option. For example:</p>
<pre><code>---
title: "EDA"
output: 
  html_document:
    toc: true
    number_sections: true
    pandoc_args: 
      ["--number-sections",
      "--number-offset=1"]
---
</code></pre>
<p><strong>Sharing our work</strong></p>
<p>Rmarkdown is fully compatible with dropbox and github. It also provides free its own cloud, <a href="http://rpubs.com/farofylax/rmarkdown">Rpubs.</a></p>
<p>Finally, you can see some rmarkdown in action <a href="http://rpubs.com/farofylax/221608">here</a> [and provide us some feedback, if you like!].</p>
<hr>
<blockquote>
<p>More resources:</p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/">webpage</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/rmarkdown-cheatsheet-2.0.pdf">cheat sheet</a></li>
<li><a href="http://kbroman.org/knitr_knutshell/pages/resources.html">even more resources</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.google.cz/search?client=ubuntu&amp;channel=fs&amp;q=r+markdown&amp;ie=utf-8&amp;oe=utf-8&amp;gfe_rd=cr&amp;ei=vk4OWPmPEuik8wfkw5kY">and always..</a></li>
</ul>
</article>
